title: BBA Aviation profits fall as low fuel prices take their toll
text:

Wed, Aug 5, 2015, 09:55 BST - UK Markets close in 6 hrs 35 mins BBA Aviation profits fall as low fuel prices take their toll By Sophie Jamieson | Telegraph – 20 minutes ago 293.60 -7.4000 
British flight services company BBA Aviation (LSE: BBA.L - news ) announced pre-tax profits down a third and revenue down 5pc following a drop in oil prices 
Low fuel prices have hit flight support company BBA Aviation, with half-year revenue down 5pc and pre-tax profit down a third. 
The FTSE 250 company said on Wednesday it remained confident of meeting growth expectations for the full year, despite reporting statutory pre-tax profits down from $92m to $61.7m. 
Underlying pre-tax profit was unchanged from 2014 at $79.2m. 
Performance was best in its US and general aviation businesses, up 1pc, while the corresponding European business was down 3pc. 
The British aviation company reported revenue of just below $1.1bn for the six months to June 30, down 5pc on 2014. But organic revenue, excluding the impact of fuel prices, foreign exchange, acquisitions and disposals was up 5pc. 
Flight support, BBA's refuelling and ground handling division, represented 76pc of the group's operating profit, with good performance driven by BBA’s Signature service for private jets. BBA described its other flight support business ASIG’s progress as “satisfactory” despite the loss of key contracts including one in Singapore. 
BBA's aftermarket services division, which provides repairs and maintenance for engines, saw underlying operating profit down a third. The weaker-than-expected performance was blamed on costs associated with its plan to rationalise and close select sites. 
BBA said it would increase its dividend by 5pc, “reflecting continued confidence in group’s future growth prospects”. 
Simon Pryce, chief executive, said the first-half performance had been good with “very strong performance” in the flight support division, and an improving performance in aftermarket services in the second quarter. 
“This, coupled with a continued, albeit slow, recovery in our major markets gives us confidence that 2015 will be a year of good growth with strong momentum into 2016," he said.
